downloadFile(user_id, file_id)

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.

---

For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month
response_text:
The provided document does not specifically discuss or require using a service mesh for WhatsApp Messenger. Instead, the architecture is based on microservices with separate services handling different aspects like user authentication (OAuth), chat functionality including one-on-one and group conversations, media sharing capabilities, push notifications, message delivery acknowledgment system, low latency communication through Kafka and Redis cache for efficient data retrieval.

The document details the functional requirements of WhatsApp messenger in terms of conversation support, user identification with OAuth mechanism via Google or Facebook account linking (optional), shared media files functionality including images, audio, video sharing capabilities along with acknowledgment system that informs users about their message's delivery status - sent/delivered and read. It also addresses the need for low latency messaging service using Kafka alongside Redis cache to minimize data replication overhead from MySQL database cluster which is geographically distributed in multiple secondary replicas, further aiding lowering system response time during peak usage periods like New Year or Christmas celebrations when user activity surges.

The document also details the non-functional requirement of message consistency and delivery order maintenance to ensure messages are delivered accurately reflective of their original sequence as per sender's intentions without data loss, ensnering system stability during peak traffic times. The WhatsApp Messenger employs this approach alongside websocket protocol for realtime communication while providing offline message storage until the receiver goes online to retrieve messages from server end which in turn notifies user of new incoming messages through push notifications mechanism when they are back online, thus enhancing system responsiveness and continuity.

Finally, it describes how a group service holds information about users within each WhatsApp Group with their IDs, status (online/offline), number of members in the chat etc., while leveraging multiple geographically distributed MySQL database clusters along with Redis cache server for efficient data retrieval and management. 

The API design section details how to send messages through WebSocket connection by providing required fields such as message_ID, sender_id/reciever_id (depending if it is one-on-one or group conversation), type of the sent message along with optional media file attachment or document sharing. It further explains that on receipt and acknowledgment from recieving end to delivery status backed by notification system for successful deliveries, reads etc., thus ensuring transparency in messaging activity between users within an application ecosystem.

In terms of data model design details are not explicitly provided but the document suggests a robust handling mechanism involving user-device connection mapping with websocket server and message service communications to ensure smooth flow of one-on-one or group conversations via Kafka topic, acknowledgment system along with push notifications for offline users.

In terms of technical architecture details such as load balancing across the cluster servers are not explicitly mentioned but it is implied through mentions of geographically distributed MySQL database clusters and Redis cache server usage to minimize latency during peak traffic times thereby ensuring optimal performance under varying system loads, which in turn can help handle additional service requests if needed.

We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.

---

Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
Data Model Design:
API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:

---

Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:

---

For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month

query: Is there any mention of optimizing the size of AI/ML models?
context_text:
Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
High-Level-Design-(HLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

---

The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

---

Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
Data Model Design:
API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:

---

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

---

Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.

---

4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.

---

API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)

---

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.
Data Model Design:
Data-Model-Design

---

For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month

---

response_text:
No, there is no specific mention in your provided text about optimization techniques for artificial intelligence (AI) or machine learning (ML) model sizes. Your focus seems to be on a real-time messaging platform's functional and non-functional requirements using microservices architecture with components like Kafka and Redis cache servers supporting features such as message delivery acknowledgment, sharing media files, chat storage when offline users are online via push notifications, low latency for immediate receipt of messages, consistency in the order of delivered messages, end-to-end encryption ensuring privacy from WhatsApp's infrastructure to maintain confidentiality. Capacity estimation is provided with a projection into 30 days based on message data size estimates per day.

If you are looking for ways to optimize AI/ML model sizes in such an application, this often involves techniques like pruning (removing unnecessary parts of the neural network), quantization (reducing the precision of the numerical representation), knowledge distillation (training a smaller "student" model from data produced by a larger one without compromising performance significantly) or using efficient architectures designed for mobile and edge devices. These strategies could potentially help if your system involves AI-based functionalities, though they were not part of the details provided in this description.

High-Level-Design-(HLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

---

Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger

API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:

---

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

---

Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.

---

4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.

---

API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)

---

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.
Data Model Design:
Data-Model-Design

The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

It focuses primarily on the system design, communication protocol between clients and servers through WebSockets, Kafka messages handling, data model, API designs, database considerations (MySQL cluster with Redis cache), as well as various requirements like low latency, message delivery order consistency, conversation capabilities including group messaging.

However, since this isn't mentioned in your document excerpt, I cannot confirm any plans regarding AI model deployment on edge devices based solely on the provided information about WhatsApp system design.

response_text:
The provided WhatsApp messenger system design document does not explicitly mention the use of specific data storage solutions such as Parquet, Avro, ORC, etc. However, it is implied that performance optimization and low latency are essential aspects due to requirements for acknowledgment mechanisms (sent/delivered), consistency in message delivery order, group messaging capabilities with geographically distributed replicas of the MySQL database cluster as well as Redis cache usage. These hints at a requirement for an efficient data handling system capable of dealing with large volumes and providing quick access to frequently read or updated records (like active/inactive user statuses).

Given this context, while not directly mentioned in your document excerpt here are the reasons that might lead you towards considering Parquet-based file formats:

1. **Columnar Storage** - Since WhatsApp heavily relies on text messages and acknowledgments which likely involve numerous user actions per day/minute (sending, reading), a columnar storage format like Parquet could be beneficial for optimizing read operations by loading only necessary columns of data into memory at any given time.
   
2. **Efficiency in IO** - For the low latency requirement and high throughput demands on group messaging services with potentially large chunks of user activity, reducing I/O wait times is crucial. Parquet files are compressed by default which can decrease disk storage costs while keeping access fast due to their efficient encoding schemes.
   
3. **Support for Complex Queries** - As the system scales and more complex queries or aggregations become necessary (for example, leaderboards based on activity within groups), columnar formats like Parquet would enable such computations with less I/O overhead compared to row-based storage systems due to their ability to skip unnecessary data.
   
4. **Integration** - The system design document mentions the use of a MySQL database cluster and Redis cache, which are not designed for processing large files or handling massive amounts of unstructured text efficiently by default. Integrating Parquet-formatted storage could be considered if there's a need to store derived datasets that might benefit from such an approach (e.g., user activity logs).
   
5. **Scalability** - As the system grows, and especially considering replication across geographically distributed databases for low latency access, Parquet can aid in efficient scaling due to its compact representation when dealing with large datasets that are often encountered by social media applications like WhatsApp Messenger services.

To implement a design using these features effectively would mean modifying the system's data models and service interactions around storage systems known for high performance on such tasks, possibly integrating Parquet formats into your MySQL database or as an additional layer of file-based caching/storage alongside Redis if appropriate in terms of consistency guarantees.

In summary, while not mentioned explicitly in the document you provided, a modern messaging service with WhatsApp's level of user activity and interaction patterns might find significant benefits from incorporating efficient data formats like Parquet for certain use cases to improve performance under high load conditions.

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.', metadata={'id': 'documentsFromText/Whatsapp/content.txt:None:10', 'source': 'documentsFromText/Whatsapp/content.txt'}), Document(page_content='The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.', metadata={'id': 'documentsFromText/Whatsapp/content.txt:None:11', 'source': 'documentsFromText/Whatsapp/content.txt'}), Document(page_content='For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month', metadata={'id': 'documentsFromText/Whatsapp/content.txt:None:4', 'source': 'documentsFromText/Whatsapp/content.txt'})]
explanation:
ed WhatsApp messenger system design document does not explicitly mention the use of specific data storage solutions such as Parquet, Avro, ORC, etc. However, it is implied that performance optimization and low latency are essential aspects due to requirements for acknowledgment mechanisms (sent/delivered), consistency in message delivery order, group messaging capabilities with geographically distributed replicas of the MySQL database cluster as well as Redis cache usage. These hints at a requirement for an efficient data handling system capable of dealing with large volumes and providing quick access to frequently read or updated records (like active/inactive user statuses).

Given this context, while not directly mentioned in your document excerpt here are the reasons that might lead you towards considering Parquet-based file formats:

1. **Columnar Storage** - Since WhatsApp heavily relies on text messages and acknowledgments which likely involve numerous user actions per day/minute (sending, reading), a columnar storage format like Parquet could be beneficial for optimizing read operations by loading only necessary columns of data into memory at any given time.
   
2. **Efficiency in IO** - For the low latency requirement and high throughput demands on group messaging services with potentially large chunks of user activity, reducing I/O wait times is crucial. Parquet files are compressed by default which can decrease disk storage costs while keeping access fast due to their efficient encoding schemes.
   
3. **Support for Complex Queries** - As the system scales and more complex queries or aggregations become necessary (for example, leaderboards based on activity within groups), columnar formats like Parquet would enable such computations with less I/O overhead compared to row-based storage systems due to their ability to skip unnecessary data.
   
4. **Integration** - The system design document mentions the use of a MySQL database cluster and Redis cache, which are not designed for processing large files or handling massive amounts of unstructured text efficiently by default. Integrating Parquet-formatted storage could be considered if there's a need to store derived datasets that might benefit from such an approach (e.g., user activity logs).
   
5. **Scalability** - As the system grows, and especially considering replication across geographically distributed databases for low latency access, Parquet can aid in efficient scaling due to its compact representation when dealing with large datasets that are often encountered by social media applications like WhatsApp Messenger services.

To implement a design using these features effectively would mean modifying the system's data models and service interactions around storage systems known for high performance on such tasks, possibly integrating Parquet formats into your MySQL database or as an additional layer of file-based caching/storage alongside Redis if appropriate in terms of consistency guarantees.

In summary, while not mentioned explicitly in the document you provided, a modern messaging service with WhatsApp's level of user activity and interaction patterns might find significant benefits from incorporating efficient data formats like Parquet for certain use cases to improve performance under high load conditions.

query: Is there any mention of selecting a more energy-efficient AI/ML framework, such as those built on programming languages like C/C++?
context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:

---

Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
High-Level-Design-(HLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

---

Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
Data Model Design:
API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:

---

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

---

Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.

---

4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.

---

API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)

---

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.
Data Model Design:
Data-Model-Design

---

The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

---

For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month
response_text:
No direct mentions or discussions about switching to an alternative and potentially more efficient AI/ML framework written in lower-level languages (like C/C++) are present within the given context. The provided information mainly focuses on designing a WhatsApp Messenger system with specified requirements, high level designs for messaging communication between clients using WebSocket servers, as well as details about data model and API design specific to chat functionality including group messages handling.

The main performance aspects mentioned in the text are related to achsieving low latency message delivery, ensuring consistency (message order), supporting one-to-one and group conversations, offline messaging storage capability with push notifications for when users come back online, acknowledgment of sent messages from both sender and receiver perspectives.

While the text details a system built on top of Redis cache servers distributed geographically to aid in reducing latency as well as MySQL database cluster utilization which may involve some level of efficiency considerations, there isn't an explicit mention or suggestion made regarding reconsidering AI/ML frameworks for their potential energy-efficiency.

In general system design and architecture decisions like these are typically based on a variety of factors including but not limited to performance (latency), reliability, scalability, manageability as well the nature & requirements of workload(s). These aspects seemingly drive our understanding from this context about why Python or Node.js might be chosen for WhatsApp Messenger implementation over other languages like C/C++ and frameworks built on top them (like TensorFlow Lite), rather than their energy efficiency per se as the primary driving factor in such a high level decision making process.

If an alternative choice of AI or ML framework based on lower-level language were being considered, it would typically be due to considerations that are specific and not covered within this context - like real-time analytics which may require low latency (that seems already addressed here), need for fine control over memory usage & resources management etc., but these aspects aren't directly stated or implied in the given text.

context_text:
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.
Availability: The system should be highly available. However, the availability can be compromised in the interest of consistency.
Security: The system must be secure via end-to-end encryption. The end-to-end encryption ensures that only the two communicating parties can see the content of messages. Nobody in between, not even WhatsApp, should have access.
Scalability: The system should be highly scalable to support an ever-increasing number of users and messages per day.
Capacity Estimation
Storage Estimation:
100 billion messages are shared through WhatsApp per day and each message takes 100 bytes on average
100 billion/day∗100 Bytes = 10 TB/day
For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:

---

Bandwidth Estimation:
According to the storage capacity estimation, our service will get 10TB of data each day, giving us a bandwidth of 926 Mb/s.
10 TB/86400sec ≈ 926Mb/s

Number of servers estimation:
WhatsApp handles around 10 million connections on a single server, which seems quite high for a server.
No. of servers = Total connections per day/No. of connections per server = 2 billion/10 million = 200 servers
So, according to the above estimates, we require 200 chat servers.

High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
High-Level-Design-(HLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

---

Important Topics for WhatsApp System Design

Requirements
Capacity Estimation
High Level Design (HLD) of WhatsApp Messenger
Data Model Design:
API Design
Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Approach to achieve the below system attributes
Requirements
The WhatsApp messenger design should meet below requirements:

---

Functional Requirement
Conversation: The system should support one-on-one and group conversations between users.
Acknowledgment: The system should support message delivery acknowledgment, such as sent, delivered, and read.
Sharing: The system should support sharing of media files, such as images, videos, and audio.
Chat storage: The system must support the persistent storage of chat messages when a user is offline until the successful delivery of messages.
Push notifications: The system should be able to notify offline users of new messages once their status becomes online.
Non-Functional Requirement
Low latency: Users should be able to receive messages with low latency.
Consistency: Messages should be delivered in the order they were sent.

---

Now, here comes the responsibility of the group service. The group service keeps all information about users in each group in the system. It has all the information about each group, including user IDs, group ID, status, group icon, number of users, and so on. This service resides on top of the MySQL database cluster, with multiple secondary replicas distributed geographically. A Redis cache server also exists to cache data from the MySQL servers. Both geographically distributed replicas and Redis cache aid in reducing latency.

The group message handler communicates with the group service to retrieve data of Group/A users. In the last step, the group message handler follows the same process as a WebSocket server and delivers the message to each user.

---

4. Support for Group messages
Since user A is connected to a WebSocket server, it sends a message to the message service intended for Group A.The message service sends the message to Kafka with other specific information about the group. The message is saved there for further processing. In Kafka terminology, a group can be a topic, and the senders and receivers can be producers and consumers, respectively.

---

API Design
Send message
sendMessage(message_ID, sender_ID, reciever_ID, type, text=none, media_object=none, document=none)

---

The following steps describe the communication between both clients:

User A and user B create a communication channel with the chat server.
User A sends a message to the chat server.
Upon receiving the message, the chat server acknowledges back to user A.
The chat server sends the message to user B and stores the message in the database if the receiver’s status is offline.
User B sends an acknowledgment to the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that the message has been successfully delivered.
When user B reads the message, the application notifies the chat server.
The chat server notifies user A that user B has read the message.
Data Model Design:
Data-Model-Design

---

Download Media File
downloadFile(user_id, file_id)

Architecture
We will be using microservices architecture since it will make it easier to horizontally scale and decouple our services. Each service will have ownership of its own data model.

Low Level Design (LLD) of System Design
Low-Level-Design(LLD)-of-WhatsApp-Messenger

1. Connection with Websocket Server
In WhatsApp, each active device is connected with a WebSocket server via WebSocket protocol. A WebSocket server keeps the connection open with all the active (online) users. Since one server isn’t enough to handle billions of devices, there should be enough servers to handle billions of users.

---

The responsibility of each of these servers is to provide a port to every online user. The mapping between servers, ports, and users is stored in the WebSocket manager that resides on top of a cluster of the data store. In this case, that’s Redis.

2. Send or receive messages
The WebSocket manager is responsible for maintaining a mapping between an active user and a port assigned to the user. Whenever a user is connected to another WebSocket server, this information will be updated in the data store. A WebSocket server also communicates with another service called message service.

---

For 30 days, the storage capacity would become the following:
30∗10 TB/day = 300 TB/month
response_text:
The given document does not explicitly discuss choosing specific hardware configurations (e.g., CPU, memory) for running instances in a Kubernetes cluster on Google Cloud Platform GCP. Similarly, it doesn't detail which Virtual Machine (VM) Instance Types to use when utilizing Compute Engine services from GCP or any other cloud provider like AWS EC2.

For such decisions regarding hardware and VM instance types for an application like a WhatsApp-like messenger service on Google Cloud Platform, you would typically consider factors like the expected load (number of concurrent users/connections), required performance levels in terms of response times or latency thresholds set by functional requirements.

Since I didn't find any specific recommendations about hardware selection within your provided document related to WhatsApp messenger system design, here are some general guidelines you can follow: 

- **Performance Needs and Cost**: Start with a basic instance type that meets the minimum performance needs for handling user connections (WebSocket) along with message storage. Then iteratively upgrade your resources if needed based on load testing results while also considering cost efficiency to prevent unnecessary spending. Tools like Cloud Load Balancer or Amazon Elastic Load Balancer can be used alongside Kubernetes' Ingress Controller and Service Mesh technologies for handling traffic distribution efficiently across multiple instances, ensuring that the system scales horizontally when needed.
- **Instance Types**: Google provides a wide range of instance types from their Compute Engine with different memory (RAM), CPU options suitable to handle varying loads which you can choose based on your expected workload and budget constraints. Some popular ones for serving web applications are Standard_D12s, N1 or P3 machines that provide high network IO capabilities ideal for handling connections in a highly concurrent environment like messaging system where many users could be sending/receiving messages simultaneously
- **Machine Types**: When deploying with Google Cloud Kubernetes Engine (GKE), you should choose the right machine types as well. Machine type 'e2' is good to start with and then upgrade based on testing requirements, but also consider using autoscaler that automatically scales your pods in or out within a cluster depending upon the demand for resources during different times of day
- **GPU Resources**: If you anticipate heavy computations (like media processing), it may make sense to include GPU options like Tesla K80/P4 into your architecture. However, this is usually not needed in messaging applications unless there are some specific background tasks that require intensive computation or image and video analysis
- **Persistence**: For persistent storage of chat messages as per requirement, Google Cloud Filestore can be used where you create a file share for each group with the necessary permissions. This way when users connect/disconnect from WebSocket server they will access this shared data instead which is effectively treated like database here but offers better performance due to lower latency 
- **Replication & Backup**: Ensure replication of critical application state across multiple zones and availability domains in case a disaster occurs. You can use solutions such as Cloud SQL or GCS for managing your MySQL/PostgreSQL databases which will automatically fail over (or up) to standby nodes when the primary one fails, ensuring high-availability of service with minimal downtime
- **Monitoring & Logging**: Use Google StackDriver and its extensions like Operations suite for monitoring application performance in real time. It helps you set alerts based on predefined thresholds or anomaly detection which is critical to ensuring the system remains responsive at all times 
- **Security Considerations**: Make sure to use SSL/TLS encryption when establishing WebSocket connections between clients and server as well as encrypt sensitive data in database. Ensure proper access controls are set up for different services that have their own respective databases or other storage systems, following the principle of least privilege
- **Redis Caching**: If appropriate based on your caching requirements to reduce latency (and cost), consider using Redis Cache Cluster with multiple read replicas. This can serve as a cache for frequently accessed data from MySQL/PostgreSQL and also provide atomic operations when updating the chat status of users in real-time
- **Push Notifications**: Leverage Firebase Cloud Messaging or similar service (Google's solution is PubSub) to send push notifications about new messages whenever user becomes online. You can set up subscriptions based on specific groups/channels and notify them accordingly 
- **Data Model & API Design**: Make sure your database schema supports storing metadata related with each message, like timestamp, sender ID, receiver ID etc., which will be helpful in maintaining consistency (as per requirement). Also make the messaging service APIs RESTful or GraphQL based for easier consumption from other parts of system
- **Rate Limiting**: As a safety measure to prevent spamming/abuse and also manage cost efficiently, consider using rate limiting at API Gateway level. This helps in controlling number of messages that can be sent by users per minute or second so as not overloading the backend 
- **Test & Load Balancing**: Make sure you set up continuous load testing with tools like Gatling/JMeter to simulate heavy traffic (e.g., when multiple groups have a large amount of concurrent chats) and then make changes if needed in your infrastructure setup or scale horizontally 
- **Disaster Recovery**: For setting up the database backup strategy, consider using Cloud SQL's automatic backups which will help you restore to most recent state without affecting performance. Also ensure that data consistency is maintained during such operations by considering eventual synchronization of file shares in case your chat messages are stored as files (as per requirement) 
- **Network Latency Considerations**: Make sure the network latency between users and server does not exceed predefined thresholds. In order to maintain global availability, consider using Google Cloud CDN service for serving static assets of application so that content delivery is faster from different regions around world which will improve overall experience 
- **Multi-Region Deployment**: If necessary based on your expected user base location and reliance needs (high latency can affect the responsiveness in some cases), consider deploying messaging services across multiple zones/regions with inter-region replication for failover capabilities. This will provide users better experience by keeping their conversations close to them physically, but also ensure that service stays available even if one region fails 
- **Cross Region Replication**: As mentioned above in the case of MySQL or PostgreSQL databases use multi regional master/slave setup with synchronous replication for maintaining data consistency across different regions. It helps keep your database state consistent while providing high availability to users by routing their requests based on geographic location
- **Cost Optimization**: Make sure you monitor the costs closely and optimize it where necessary like using autoscale policies, choosing right pricing tiers for storage etc 

These are some broad guidelines that can be followed. But always consider to choose a suitable provider based on your specific requirements & budget as different cloud providers (e.g., AWS/Azure) offer similar services with their own unique features and advantages, which might prove more beneficial for you in the long run
Here is an example of how you could set up Redis cache cluster: 

- Firstly decide on your caching strategy like LRU or write through etc based upon use case. For messaging app its usually read-through pattern with user statuses as most frequently accessed data
- Create a redis Cache Cluster by creating multiple replicas in different availability zones of same region and configure them to be master/slave setup for failover capabilities 
- Setup your Redis instance so that whenever any message is sent or received, it's also stored (with relevant metadata) into MySQL/PostgreSQL DB directly. This way when user becomes online he can immediately read his offline messages without waiting until the data reach to database replicas of this particular zone 
- Make sure your application logic and Redis Cache Cluster is set up such that whenever a new message arrives, it's either stored into cache or updated if already present in cache. When user becomes online from his side he will always get messages not only form DB but also cached ones until the time of last update to database
- Use Google Stackdriver metrics & logs for monitoring Redis Cache Cluster health and performance stats
